top_comment.text:
I will never understand the reason why people like these movies, its 
similar to the horror genre in terms of formulaic except that the horror 
genre has a lot more appeal: scares, blood, suspense and it is not gender 
centric so it appeals to more then one demographic. These all end up the 
same using the same tropes and stereotypes without having anything to back 
it up. A great example of breaking the mold would be 21 jump street where 
all the cool kids were the nerds etc. and that everyone questions the age 
of the leads as being high school students when clearly they were adults. 
Not to mention how you can find any of the characters likable as their 
stereotypes deems them so, like how can the lead find the jock as a love 
interest(which it will by the mid point of the movie) when he calls her by 
such standards. How can we like the lead when she can't be herself but has 
to bend and mold herself into what everyone wants her to be?﻿
top_comment.author: Smack Chop

comments.text: +Skyebright1 couldn't agree more.
comments.author: Smack Chop

top_comment.text:
Hello, Grace:) I'm not sure if this question warrants a video response, but 
I would like to know your thoughts as to why Hollywood insists on casting 
actors who are *clearly* not teenagers, in movies about High School 
students, aka teens! Both leads in The Duff (Robbie Amell and Mae Whitman) 
are 26 years of age! Granted, Mae Whitman could pass for 19, but Amell is 
no doubt beyond his pubescent years. Could there be a shortage of younger 
talent, or does Hollywood simply insist on making teens feel physically 
inadequate? Perhaps X-Men Apocalypse will break this trend?  Thanks, 
Grace:) Beyond the Trailer has been a huge inspiration on my life, and I 
hope to cover movies, as you do, after graduation! Cheers:)     ﻿
top_comment.author: Earl Marshall

comments.text:
When you're an adult and you look at some teenagers, it's like - wow they 
look like little kids.  But when you're *in* highschool it feels like you 
and your friends all look like 'grown ups' maybe just with less wrinkles. 
So Teens still relate to people in their 20s playing teenagers.  They don't 
*look* incorrect to them, even though they should look a lot younger.

comments.author: Alizha Sanchez

top_comment.text:
DUFF, according to this movie, is supposed to stand for Designated Ugly Fat 
Friend. How does the lead actress in this movie fit the definition of ugly 
or fat? She is far from fat, and she is not ugly. She has an attractive 
girl next door look. The vast majority of regular guys would find her 
attractive. She might not be bombshell attractive or Victoria Secret 
attractive, but she has an everyday beauty. In terms of her weight, there 
is probably a meager 5 lbs difference between her and her "hot" friends. 
This is hardly significant. If Hollywood is attempting to make a movie to 
appeal to the esteem of "regular" girls, who have body image issues, this 
is not a good example. If the producers of this movie are really interested 
in offering a social critique, they should have hired an actress that was 
the exact antithesis of the Hollywood ideal- not someone who looks very 
close to the ideal, but is just missing a few features or has a minuscule 
amount of extra weight. They need to hire a girl who really looks heavy, 
and whose face is really unattractive. Then the movie would have the right 
to be called a bold social commentary. This is still playing it safe. This 
movie reminds me of "She Is All That", a movie that came out 1999. That 
film had the audacity to portray Rachael Leigh Cook, a woman who is 
exceptionally good looking, as a nerdy "unattractive girl" by putting 
glasses and frumpy clothes on her. It didn't fool anyone. ﻿
top_comment.author: Drake Santiago

comments.text:
The film, at least to me, is about showing that no one is ugly and everyone 
is someone's duff no matter how pretty or thin and in the book Wesley in 
the end line says 'you look beautiful tonight, Bianca' so yeah it's not 
about calling that particular actress fat or ugly etc.

comments.text: Good point.
comments.author: letsdreamthatdream

top_comment.text:
One of the finest example of why I rag on Hollywood and "mainstream" 
audiences. Grace called out Best Man's Holiday for having only one white 
character, but there is no mention of how Ken Jeong is the only person of 
color in this trailer and probably in the whole movie.

What is it about Duff or Fault in Our Stars that will make them instant 
classics or have strong cult fanbases but not Beyond the Lights. They're 
all formulaic; we basically know how each of these movies will turn out, 
the leads are all attractive, the themes are universal, so... just what is 
it?

I understand that Grace is talking about the likely success of this movie, 
and I agree with her assessment; however, I'm sick to death of movies that 
seem to only differ from each other in the race of its cast but they are 
not being received by audiences with the same level of enthusiasm. But of 
course it's never about the racism of white audiences, they aren't telling 
Hollywood and Hollywood isn't listening to them that they want and need 
white faces on screen so they can engage and identify with the characters.

Evidenced by how they consistently refuse to support movies starring actors 
of color and instead of confronting their own racial preferences they blame 
black, Asian, and Latino productions for being too esoterically ethnic. 
Without even a second thought that they could be doing the same thing to 
audiences of color with their all/ mostly white casts in movies. White 
faces, experiences, and perspectives are so universal that white actors can 
even play people of color more *effectively* than actors of the original 
race or ethnicity.﻿
top_comment.author: Tebigong101

background. meh -_-
